author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
It seems to me that 99% of Engineers and Producers have this arc. Initial freedom and playfulness, and then a significant period in the wilderness where “getting it right” or “being professional” takes over while they build their technical skills and experience

Some much smaller percentage emerge from this period back into a playful lightness (while having integrated the skills). I would say less engineers than producers IME

The thing is that it really doesn’t need to be that way, and it’s probably my #1 motivator in posting here - to keep the focus on what matters. Art and play and the human connection it allows is the goal, and no 15 year old girl cares what mic you used on the hi hat

author: BatMeckley
content:
Couple things:
1) no one is actually a perfectionist. It doesn’t exist. I heard a great story of someone telling (I want to say) Richard Marx that he hadn’t released his record yet cause he’s a perfectionist and RM replied “Bullshit. Name one thing you’ve ever done that’s actually perfect. You’re just scared to move on.”  That story has stuck with me.

2) I’m a fairly decent guitar player, have made an actual career of being paid to do it. And I STILL am either constantly hiring people better than I or recording things note by note and then assembled in protools afterwards. Dr Luke might be the best guitarist I’ve ever been around (and I’ve hung with Blake Mills, Tim Pierce, Phil X), and he CONSTANTLY would just hit record, play the four chords of the song free time, and then cut them up and drop them on the ones or wherever they’re supposed to go in the song. My favorite thing about making records vs performing them live is that on record NO ONE CARES how you got there, just that you did. Unless your groove has something particularly magic to offer I’d get over the one take mentality pretty quick.

author: Rollmottle
content:
How to simultaneously operate as if there are no stakes, while being in the chair with real stakes at play? Some questions I ask myself:

Do I instinctively know the tools I have? Do I operate whatever tools I choose as if they’re an extension of myself? Do they disappear? There’s never a question of what do we use here, you just know. You weren’t bound by your tools when you didn’t know them, why would you be bound by them knowing them cold? Embrace and commit to what you have. The new plug-in isn’t going to make you better. 

Am I operating from fear and scarcity? What will my engineer friends think of my snare? What if I release the song and nobody listens? What if I’m not as good as I think I am? What if I don’t get another client? What if I can’t make rent? These can all creep in to make what was once fun and playful, “work.” But you probably didn’t get into this to do “work.” Success is built over time, not whether you fucked the snare tone that one time. Be OK with failure. Embrace it. Then, ask yourself: do you *really* have anything to lose?

Do you know who you are? You’re not Shawn Everett or Jon Castelli or Serban. You’re you. Stop trying to parse what Castelli would do and start knowing what you’re going to do. Run towards your idiosyncrasies. Embrace them. Become undeniably you because I bet whatever you did years ago was unmistakably you.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Someone in the mix channel had mused about what Serbian’s assistant’s do, and it brings me back to “The people that know how will always work for the people that know why”

Do you know the actual reasons why you feel your work doesn’t measure up yet? Hint: it’s very rarely strictly the sonics and/or mix. That Olivia Rodrigo album sounded objectively terrible, but FELT awesome. And that’s what mattered in the end.  Benny Blanco became successful with a folder full of songs at 120 bpm cause he didn’t know how to change the tempo, and stacks of kick drums because he didn’t know how to eq (he just layers a brighter kick on top if it needs more snap). When I’d ask him why he pretty much did anything it was always “I dunno, man, it just sounds cool!”. Make sure you’re attacking the work with that kind of mindset. 

When I get lost in the minutiae I try to zoom out and just be like “does this whole track feel good? Am I instinctually bobbing my head?” And if not, why?

95% of the songs that people have sent me here, the issue hasn’t been their space, or their monitoring, or whether they used a 60s or 70s guitar, or if they mixed analog or in the box. The issues almost always tend to be much less narrow in scope. Make sure you zoom out and just go “is this cool?”

author: popaganda.
content: I’ve been deep-diving on Daniel Johns this last week and really been thinking about the toll that being creative can take on people. It came up yesterday in the VC too. In some ways our culture likes to reward artists being martyrs, but it’s never something to strive for. I think as producers one of the biggest parts of our job is to be a grounding presence and a support for artists who can sometimes have pretty wild swings. But we’re artists too in our own right with our own bipolar tendencies. In a way that can create an empathy bond between us…we can understand the manic exuberance of making an amazing thing and how there’s usually a pendulum swing in the other direction to compensate. But I kind of think our job as producers is to have our shit together enough to buffer that bipolar thing and make a sanctuary where an artist can feel at home. Just my random thought for the day.

author: ALXCPH
content:
I've been a "musician" since way before i started recording and producing stuff. (Since i was 4 i think). It's such an integral part of how music can feel and make you move. Think about how someone like Anderson paak. can make you dance by just playing 8th notes on a highhat and nothing else(see tinydesk for ref.) or Pino Paladino, will make you break your neck with his bass, playing simple Quater notes. (anything D'angelo).  Even in a genre that is as quantized and on the grid as it gets like a lot of hiphop/trap is, notice how the artist(rappers) that really stand out, are the ones that make those beats really groove/hit because of how they themselves "groove" or flow on those beats. They might be slightly behind or in front of the beat, or they might even swing a little. 

You can really get into the micro and macro dynamics of groove. Listen to guys like Led zeppelin, how they might start out a song a few BPM slower than they finish, because of the build up of energy through out the song, and it doesn't sound wrong or unnatural. 

A fun thing to do, when looking for inspiration for grooves, is record some foley, and look for naturally occurring rhythms in the sample. Try and build a grove around that probably a bit wonky rhythm. It can really be an eye opening experience once you realise how much fun rhythm and groove is, when you don't have to obey the grid in a daw like a machine. 

But like anything music, it's really about listening and feeling. Really internalising what a forward or laid back snare feels like or a bass thats almost a 16th behind the beat.

author: Zack Hames
content:
You’re gonna hate this. But the best way is to just get more reps to get faster and better. 10,000 hours, no shortcuts.

But more actionable advice - stick to a slim number of EQ and Compressor plugs and just use those. For example 99% of my mixes just use pro q3, API-2500, and Kush AR-1. The idea being minimize variables and decisions, and use stuff you know ridiculously well.

Production side, I find having go to sounds, samples, and instruments (hardware or software) well learned and ready to go shortens the path from opening your project to creating music. For me, this is taking my free time to mess with my MPC and explore samples, or to create patches on my synths to become more intertwined with my instruments. This is separate from the actual “I’m gonna make a song today” process.

Ultimately…make a song in 8 hours as many days as you can. If you TRY every day, that’s better than nothing. By the end of a month, even if you only made FOUR tracks…that’s better than nothing and it just adds up.

author: Slow Hand
content:
> "How are y'all thinking about which part of this waveform should fall on which side of the beat?"
I'm listening and not looking. Nudge. Listen. Nudge. Listen.

When it comes to groove or feel it's common for the ensemble to not line up perfectly or even *sound* as if they line up perfectly on transients. Quite often the band are flamming against each other in a way that is tasteful. Sometimes they're dead-on for a beat and the next moment they're doing a tight flam. 

Don't get lost solo'ing instruments. Keep the entire song section in perspective when you tweak. If you're having trouble making choices mute a few instruments, but don't solo.

Also, fader level has a massive influence on groove. Before you start editing too hard play with your fader balances and find the groove that way. Listen to how the proportion of instruments changes the groove. It may turn out you don't need to do much, if any, micro editing.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Granted, her examples are *very* specific to orchestra and not directly applicable to pop records, but the underlying principles here include:

**1) **Think of instrument combinations as a single composite voice.

One instrument can function as the "sustain" portion of the sound and a second instrument gives the "attack". Together they create a single melodic voice.

**2) **How do the instruments stack on each other? Do they clash? Cellos doubling a bass an octave up extend it's timbre into a higher register to make it read better. It's not so different from adding fuzz to an 808 so that it has more presence.

**3) **Which instrument will cut through the music?

---

A few concepts that I'll add:

**4) **Instruments in the foreground vs. the background. Know which part is the lead (focal point) at any given point in the record and then pare down the presence of the rest and push it into the back of the sound stage.

**5)** (Piggybacking off of Felix's excellent post) What is the simplest way to achieve the desired effect? Reduce. Reduce. Reduce.

Cut instruments and parts ruthlessly and approach it with a minimalist's eye. Like writing a haiku: How few elements can you use to create an impression? Maybe a guitar part is carrying 90% of the groove and the drums only need to be a kick and a snare. Or maybe the guitar is covering the backbeat too, and you don't even need a snare!

Constantly ask yourself "What is the most important sensation in the record?" and then focus it by cutting out everything that gets in the way.

**6)** Hocketing. Pass the melody off between different instruments at different points in the song. Play it in different registers. Combine voices occasionally for special effect.

**7)** Tonal contrast. Dark instruments plus bright instruments. Distorted and clean together. Near vs. distant.

Elements that sound same-y will gel together and elements that contrast tonally will pop.

author: BatMeckley
content:
There’s one specific actress/singer I’ve worked with a few times, and the second time she brought her mom over while we were tracking. Every time I complimented her after a take, she screwed up the next one. If I said a take was bad the next one would be great. The session quickly devolved in to me just saying increasingly awful things after every take, much to her mom’s delight who was laughing on the back couch.

I’ve said this over and over again on this server, but people skills and just sheer musical awareness and taste trump technical ability and gear every time (the how vs the why). If I’m needing Kirk to record an incendiary angry solo in the middle of a heavy, emotional song, I’m probably not gonna set up flowers in the studios and kick it off with a warm stone massage.  Your job as a producer is to get the best out of the artist, and a good producer will have a feel for what that specific artist needs.(A Rick Rubin specialty).

author: peterlabberton
content: I took a drum lesson from Victor Indrizzo a few years ago (which was super awesome), and one thing I remember is that he said he often does a pass with shaker or tambourine before doing the drums, even if it gets muted in the end. Then plays to that instead of the click. It’s more fun to play to, and it infused his feel in the track from the jump, AND it keeps him from doing too many unnecessary subdivisions on that hat or ghost notes on the snare that don’t need to be in there.

author: NoahNeedleman
bobby k
content: I will say this, on the topic of standing up for yourself -- I've seen a couple times in these threads now a general sentiment of accepting that people are gonna kick you around. It felt evident when we were riffing on sliding scale mixing rates last month and it felt evident this morning/last night in here. I'm all in on the greyhound sentiment, I've been a grafter through and through since I was in elementary school skipping homework to double up on piano practice. I once drove 7 hours to buy a Juno-60 on Craigslist and the guy didn't answer the door; I make DUMB life decisions all centered around this non-negotiable gravity towards the art. I can promise I have whatever that obsessive brain disorder thing is that we all keep riffing about (and believe the same for the grand majority here). But can we not practice a little self preservation along the way? Nobody besides your team is really gonna stick up for you; I believe that in line with the all the professional metrics there exists the opportunity/need to set  precedents on how you want to be treated. I don't think this is something that *comes* with being a great producer, I think it's something that *contributes* to someone becoming a great producer. And of course, knowing how to ask for that fairness with a kind/patient/assertive/flexible tone is critical. But if I believe something is a little crooked in the system, I'd rather not wait till I hopefully arrive a decade later on the other side of the fence to be able to do something about it. I would rather make an attempt at being heard now and see whether it makes any progress, even if it just gives some suit on an email thread something to think about. It's not for the sake of my own ego, it's for the sake of our entire breed.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@Zack Hames yeahhhh. watch the questlove video on youtube where he talks about d'angelo asking him to play crazy laid back and flammy too.

my general thought on timing is: behind the beat is more groovy and laid back (vocals, percussion, bass against the kick drum, etc) and ahead is intense and anxious (especially vocals).

there are many examples of groove being behind the beat as that's something people talk about a lot. definitely dive into that concept and play with laying different elements back off the grid.

but i LOVE talking about being ahead of the beat. purists complain that a lot of modern hip hop vocals are ahead of the beat and "off time." but when it's done well it makes the tracks SO exciting. lil durk, 21 savage, gucci, etc all have this excitement in some of the songs because the vocal are ahead. 

i've heard the argument that these guys are just amateurish in their skill. that might be true, but their natural groove and cadence works. also listen to kendrick on "Family Ties" where he goes in and out of being ahead of the beat and it sounds exciting as fuck when he does.

also "Icky Thump" by White Stripes is a song with vocals that are entirely ahead of the beat. clearly it's deliberate as jack white is a rhythmic genius (and the doubles are perfect). it adds this anxiety to the whole song that is SO dope.

author: peterlabberton
content: Under 40 hz? If we’re taking *that* low, in my experience usually kicks benefit from sitting just slightly above that range, especially in rock—somewhere around 50-60hz. Usually they sound punchier and less flabby with just a touch of the super low lows rolled off. Basses can move around a bit more, obviously, but I also find that usually even if you have a fundamental around or below 40 hz, the first harmonic an octave above is usually what you’re actually interested in. Also it’s very song/arrangement/tempo (!) dependent! A slower tempo or less busy kick pattern or song arrangement will let you get away with loads more super sub stuff. Faster patterns will just sound like flabby mush with tons of sub.

author: austenballard
content:
Test is done. Tl;dr they don't null completely. They don't even detect the same audio the same.

**INTRODUCTION**
Beckley, et al. (2023) reported differences in tuning results between the plugin and standalone versions of Melodyne. This investigator undertook a test of Melodyne plugin, ARA and standalone versions to determine whether the resulting tuned audio would null.

**METHODS**

All testing was performed at a sample rate of 48kHz and with .wav files at a bit depth of 32 bits. Tuning was tested using two 2-second square wave tones generated with FabFilter One in Logic Pro X. Tone #1 was generated at a constant pitch of C4 +50ct. Tone #2 was generated at a pitch of C4 with the following settings: Modulation Generator (MG) Frequency set to 4.033 Hz,  MG waveform set to value 0.500, and Frequency Modulation MG set to value 0.123. Each tone was printed on a separate channel as a Bounce-in-place (bip). The two bips were then joined into a single, 6-second, mono .wav file with 2 seconds of silence between the bips. The 6-second .wav file was copied onto two new channels in Logic Pro X, and dragged out of Logic Pro onto the desktop for use in Melodyne standalone.

Audio was transferred into Melodyne: one mono channel in Logic Pro X was loaded with an instance of Melodyne non-ARA, one mono channel in Logic Pro X was loaded with an instance of Melodyne ARA, and the copy of the .wav file on the desktop was loaded into Melodyne standalone. All transfers were completed using the Melodic (Standard) algorithm. 

Transferred audio was quantized to pitch C4, offset 0 ct, Pitch Modulation 0.0%, Pitch Drift 0.0%. All other settings were left at defaults; Note Assignment mode was checked to verify that Playback Type in each case was 'Tonal'. 

Resulting audio was printed and imported into three new mono channels in Logic Pro X. Null testing was performed using the phase invert feature in Logic Pro X's stock 'Gain' plugin.

author: Maxim
content:
If you want to get a kick properly, try isolating each section rather than fading. Izotope Imager is great for this. 

Just create 4 bands spread evenly and export all of these bands separately in solo. Then bring them back, stack the 4 layers and cut the noise from each band until you only hear the kick (transient). This will let you keep those long lows intact without the noise up top.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: All this Hi-hat chat reminds me of a method i’ve not seen used before anywhere else.  I made a record in Nashville a few years ago with engineer Mark Nevers (Bill Callahan, Bonnie Prince, Lambchop etc) and instead of using click tracks he had in his template a load of shakers, side sticks and percussion loops which he had recorded all set with Elastic Audio and Tick based processing. What this meant was he could create a shaker type click just by changing the blend between the samples and pushing the tempo up or down. It worked really well on what was an acoustic based record. The players loved it, and I swear they got master takes quicker without being bludgeoned by the normal click.  Anyone done this before? Is it a Nashville thing?

author: Slow Hand
content:
Three things come to mind: 

1) **Note length and envelope**. That's going to have a large influence on the feel. Electronic producers will spend a *lot* of time sculpting the volume envelope relative to the tempo. Trance producers have entire plugins that give them microscopic control over the pitch and volume envelopes of kick drums.

2) **Presentation and proportion**. Is it up-front or does it sink into the back? It's easy for a 4x4 to feel hackneyed or overbearing. Sometimes all you need is a gentle *pat pat pat pat* to tie things together.

A fresh or unconventional texture will open up drastically different feels. People can dance to anything if it's got a 4x4 click, so it doesn't necessarily *need* to be a kick. You can go far using samples and percussion that sit in different registers, but play the same role.

3) **Complimentary instruments**. If the kick is the "rock" then the groove is going to come from how everything else swings over that. What's the friction like between the kick and the other elements? If the kick is a "straight man", then the other elements pushing off of it are where the magic comes from.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah, this is a really cool approach to metronome. I once worked with an engineer who had a drum machine/sequence set up where he could fade in and blend different rhythmic subdivisions. (1/4, 1/4t, 1/8, 1/8t, 16, etc...) The samples were all shakers and pleasant sounding percussion. It was way more musical than getting pummeled by the worlds crispest woodblock on the quarter-note pulse.

He said he'd developed it after doing a lot of slow doom-y metal records that grind along at ultra-slow tempos and where the players are playing very spacious but angular rhythmic parts that needed to come in on the "+ e" of beat 3 after a 4 bar rest. Stuff like that. Having 1/16t subdivisions alongside the 1/4 pulse was really helpful for the players to come in strong when they needed to catch a really tough entrance.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Nope. I don't see why Ableton would be lacking in that way. It's perfectly capable of making great drums.

A pre-made drum loop will usually be more polished and ready-to-go than making your own drum pattern from individual samples. The pre-made loop will likely have been EQ'd, compressed, and mixed to work harmoniously, whereas if you're building a loop from scratch using samples it is up to you to polish and sculpt the sounds so that they work well together.

If the pre-made drum loop is like having someone serve you a finished meal, building the drum part from scratch means you have to learn to "cook" using those ingredients. It'll be harder to do well at first, but once you get the hang of it you'll be able to be more expressive.

It’s giving steel banglez and the Afro swing sound he made popular about 6 or 7 years ago in London ? Then we got the trap wave . Interesting one imho because there’s an unsettled debate as to whether the dembow , soca and other clave and tresillo derived pulses gave rise to the Afro beats wave that popped off in london years back (and steel banglez finessed so successfully into his (great ) productions) or if those Afro Cuban / carribean forms that have existed for hundreds of years are fundamentally derivative of the west african forms (eg nyabinghi and early New Orleans drum lines being deliberately so ) and so even if Afro beat reappropriated some carribean forms for its own modern genesis , it was only using what it gave birth to in the first place . 

Imho these beats today sit as a uk post modern take on the product of all of these wonderful rhythms from the diaspora, and like the people the rhythms themselves are all kin . I’m sure Interested also if that particular beat can be pinned down to an early african or Afro carribean form

My Mrs dad is sierra leonian creole . Which is to say his heritage is to have been the people that returned back to Sierra Leone from Jamaica . Much of the sierra leionian creole culture is a blend of carribean and west african and The music and culture tends to be somewhere along this journey most times . It travels with the people and their story is the story of the music

author: Zakhiggins
content:
Im pretty much always messing with the length of kick, snare and hat trying to get them to fit in the grove better, you can make some unlikely pairs work when you do this.

Also always messing with the order in which transients are hitting on downbeats, nudging certain drums slightly before or after others can make things mesh together real nice. Typically the higher pitched/attacky things like hi hats come earlier than the sub kicks for example but experiment with it and see what sounds good. A song where this is really obvious is say it right by nelly furtado, listen to the way the layers are stacked on the downbeats of the chorus. Side note, when you're doing this, think of everything with a transient on that downbeat as a percussion instrument.

author: Deleted User
content:
usually saw/buzz basses can’t have much perceived subs without filtering because of the amount of upper harmonics. with shorter saw bass- I usually tend to favor the upper area for punch and get the low subs from kick and if I need lengths in the lows I double it with a sub or electric bass and not use the sub from the saw bass. on saw bass with longer sustain- I like to do band pass filtering (take out subs and filter out the sizzlely highs) and use a separate sub bass in the middle and use saw bass that spreads out on the sides. 

I wouldn’t do significant boost lows on saw bass, I find it just messes with the character of the sound too much

author: Slow Hand
content:
If they're loops I always include the tempo in parentheses at the end of the file name *ex: Plaque perc loop 1 (130)*.

If they're one-shot drums I always prepend them with  *kick, snare, HH, OHH, etc* An example would be *kick Plaque 1*, *kick Plaque 2*, etc.

If it's a collection of all the sounds and loops from a finished song I create a folder for that song (with the tempo in the name) and within that folder are subfolders for *loops, drums, SFX, etc*

Finally, in addition to creating a folder with all of the assets for the songs (as I just mentioned), I copy all of the drum-hits to a single folder that has all of my custom *kicks, snares, HH, etc*. Same for any loops. This way I can search by song, but I can also go to a folder with *all* of my custom kick samples in one place.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Honestly I almost always start a live bass with UAD’s Ampeg B15. It’s ballsy as hell and there’s a lot of options for cabs, presets are all super useful. Once I’m there I hit a decap or other saturation plug with a mix knob and dial in the upper mids to “growl” a la @Slow Hand’s CLA, the I compress the fuck out of it. Depending on how much thump or how smooth I want it, I usually go with either a UAD fairchild 660 or DBX160. Dyanmic eq Side chained to the kick right at the kik fundamental, and bobs your Fucken uncle. Usually. 

Another trick that helps me usually is a static eq dip just above the fundamentals. Clearly out those lows usually helps the bottom and growl speak better for me. 

That being said- a poorly recorded or performed bass isn’t just warfare, it’s heartbreak warfare. 😯😬🤪

author: Deleted User
content: Sooo, on the recording side of things: if you’re going DI, most interfaces do not have a high enough input impedance to do passive pickups justice, especially if you want a decent amount of low end. Guitar pickups sound good with 1-2MOhm(the input impedance of a good tube amp), but if I want really clear modern low end that can compete with 808s, then I’ve had the best results with around 10MOhm on passive bass pickups. Another important thing is a transistor-based active DI will not get you a full low end. You will end up re-amping or using amp emulations etc. Octal tubes(the type of tubes IN the B15) will. Octal tubes have a lot more body(think U47, for example) and will get you there much much quicker. I have a Sarno V8, which isn’t perfect, but sounds clean, “finished” and modern from the get-go. No compression or emulations needed. It’s also comparatively affordable, so totally worth every penny.

author: Deleted User
content:
I feel you, especially in boom bap there's a lot that goes into that drunken swing feel. Same with tradition African groove. Easiest way is to load up a clip or loop from a drummer you like and extracting groove templates. You can quantize to the groove of your favorite drummer or a drum loop you dig. This will get you the results, but groove is a never ending journey of learning. Editing groove to make it feel the way you want to feel takes an understanding of what makes things groove one way or the other. It can be accents, dynamics, lengths of the notes, how much you deviate from the grid or what subdivisions you're on, and how the timing offsets rub and interact with each other in the whole instrumentation. Some drummers have really solid quintuplet swing, so instead of doing tripplet swing they'll play on the downbeat and the 3rd or 4th note of quintuplet. For this you can listen to guys like Nate Smith, he plays swings differently live than recordings- he drags and pushes the kicks and snares in recordings but for live, he only swings hats so there's more steady groove for other musicians to grab onto. 

On the other hand, for playing the grooves yourself- I find it helpful to dance and groove to the rhythms as much as I can to absorb the feel and internalize them. But in order to play ahead or behind with authority, you need to know where the grids are and metronome practice is crucial. I'm not that great at timing either, so I'm trying to do as much reps in with metronomes as I can. Learning to play on the grid is a first step before learning how to deviate with clear intention. I hope this helps!

author: spectrummasters
content: Logic Gang: quick share, Im finding the sample delay tool v useful in a few ways and reccommend for a few reasons. Picking up on the midi ticks convo last week, if youre programming in Logic , instead of dragging (and losing track of your moves) in the timeline/piano roll....throw one of these on an insert and increase the delay in tiny increments as you run down the track (typically hats and offbeat/ghost snares first) . You can quickly create the pocket youre looking for . Also added bonus...I believe under c. 12ms most people arent hearing a glaring time shift , (i dont go above 2ms ) so the delay is handy again just putting your hats , snares, percussive elements....just a millisecond or two behind/in front of each other so all your transient sounds are not hitting the 1/4,1/8, 16th counts at precisely the same instant. I find this helps with transients. Lastly, unlink the left and right on a stereo channel and youve got an instant width tool. Best for the transient and groove use tho imo.

author: Adam Thein
content:
It's really simple in Live (and I'm sure there's equivalent warp modes in other daws) - use the Repitch Warp mode, move the tempo down til you are slightly slower (the track will play back at a lower pitch), record at that new key and tempo, and warp it back up (Repitch mode on whatever you recorded).  The formants and the pitch and the tempo will all move together and playback smoothly.

I think @Ross Fortune has mentioned this before but the iOS app MusicMath has a handy tool to input the BPM and how many semitones you want to transpose and it'll kick out the correct new BPM to get the transposition you want.

The big caveat here is that this is going to be hella disruptive. It's a tear-down and that's a lot of work to start from the bottom. So probably don't open that door if you've got a pressing deadline.

author: Brian Reynolds
content: Midi hi hat pattern packs. Two reasons. First, quick drag and drop building blocks. Second, go thru your favorites and look at them closely in the midi windows. What's their velocity, length, pitch, and place on the grid. How does each hit compare to the next so on and so forth.

author: oaklandmatt
content: Copy the placement of each sound and see it on the grid. Copy the swing and you'll learn a ton about grooves. Copy the sound of the samples and you'll learn unexpected things about sample choice. Copy the mix and you'll see how they all come together

author: KushKadett
content: Dub and raggae from that era was made on old BBC consoles (very hifi and not lofi gritty in my book) There's an engineer giving a masterclass on dub mixing on youtube (great video, highly recommend it!)  and he explains how it's kind of a misconception that their equipment was all ghetto when in actuality they had incredible world class stuff left over from the brits after they left, which rivals what the best studios use even today. Analog gear hasn't really progressed much and a pultec/Neve EQ is still one of the best EQs ever for instance. Those records still sound great for that reason. As for punk and hardcore it's interesting: do people genuinely still listen to those records? I've revisited a few old punk records which I used to think were amazing. The songs are great but the listening experience just isn't enjoyable for me anymore, in part due to messy playing  and bad recording/mixing. With bad I mean the playing distracts from the groove of the band and the mixing distracts from the song, where it does not support the dynamic shifts

author: Slow Hand
content:
As a practical example of when not being in phase is the right move:

Jon Castelli did a live mix on Twitch on Wednesday that included live drums. He identified that one of the snare mics sounded fuller when he inverted the polarity and proceeded to mix with that. 

Later in that session when it came time for notes, the producer (who was present in the room) asked why the snare had lost a certain thin and "woody" character that they liked. Jon reverted the snare mic to it's original polarity and the producer went "Ahh! There it is."

So the takeaway here is that while drums usually *do* sing the best and hit the hardest when they're all working in phase with one another, sometimes the creative intention overrides the need to align them in a way that makes them most "full".

As you say: If it sounds good, it is good.

(It’s all super project dependant) If I’m both producing and tracking I’ll often just get the production to a point where it’s good to write to and simple enough to have ideas flow. Then throw it into a vocal tracking session and get the demo vocals and get the song written and record a few too many parts. Then produce the song around the song and vocals. Usually I’ll have beat and vocals separate, but sometimes it makes more sense to have in the same session. Depends on the song. But I always track over a 2 track. Because it takes a lot of risk out of having some random synth or plug-in chain from the production mess up the session while trying to get good takes with the artist.(total buzzkill if you have to restart a session when the vocalist is in the zone) 
But again soooooo project dependant. Depends on how the artist likes to work, time line, amount of sessions that are possible to have together and so on. Sometimes you’ll only have one day with an artist, and if you are also producing, leave all the cool production tricks til later and get the best vocals you can get.

author: Daniel Ross
content: I feel like groove is so subjective so we’re probably all wrong and all right to some degree…but I almost never let my bass be off grid. I always find the impact lessened when I do. Something about a lack of confidence in the low end makes me like the song less. There are exceptions but they are rare imo. And I hardly ever let the down beats of transitions be off grid too. I usually want the sections to be obvious. I also start with going behind the beat first. I have also recently in the last year or so found that if I start with getting the very basic part of the groove right first, I am less likely to overcrowd my production. So before I put hats in, I’ll just put in snare and kick and try and find the groove with just those 2 elements (unless there is some other clear rhythmic element at play) but I feel like if you can’t feel the groove with just the kick and (snare/clap/perc) then it’s not there.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I agree with @BatMeckley's approach on this. Have them execute your vision, and then once you have it let them go wild and swing big. Try something new.

It's up to either the artist or you, as the producer, to have a vision for what the song is, where it's going, and what it needs. One of you have to have a roadmap. *Someone* needs to have the vision. To be the leader. To steer the ship.

If the vision is not clear then perhaps the song itself needs to be refined some more until it has a strong identity. That will be your north star for creative decisions. 

If you can convey the essence of the song to your players, the emotion behind it, then they can interpret that feeling in a way that is uniquely them without the need for you to dictate their parts. If you can give them an emotion and maybe some general contour of what you're hearing then they can fill in the spaces and bring their own qualities.

As producer, part of your job is curating the talent that you recruit to realize your vision. If you know what the song needs you can confidently pick a player with complimentary sensibilities. If you can pick the right person then very often most of the work is done by virtue of them being aligned with the song. Each of their contributions and ideas are likely to be excellent.

----

author: Slow Hand
content:
If you're concerned about being too suggestive to the players about their parts then strip back the demo until it contains only the most essential parts. No fancy stuff. Just chords, melody, and lyric. *Maybe* a kick drum pattern. Lead sheet style.

If the song is good then it will still be compelling. The best songs tend to be very robust and can be played a dozen different ways because they are fundamentally compelling. If the demo doesn't feel good this way then the song may need more work.

Lesser songs will depend on the arrangement or production to be compelling, or only work in a narrow band of styles. Sometimes a song can only work one way. It's okay if this is the case for your song, but then it's up to you to present the demo with the arrangement or elements that are essential to make the song compelling, and that will close off more and more of the instrumental possibilities.

So if you want to increase the chances of a session player delivering an unexpected, brilliant, idea then set them up for success with a strong song that can be interpreted many ways.

----

content:
What this guy Said! 👆a great Groove by great players on the way in usually needs very little work. 
If you do have to edit, going completely on grid i almost never the way to get “Groove”.
If you listen to how they interact try and feel why its not grooving. Are some beats rushed or maybe too sluggish? The best grooves are usually a little bit of very consistant not on beatness. 

Other than that you could have something that does Groove on the Way in, but if the rest of the material isnt grooving with it, things will still Sound off. 

Groove is instinctual and intentional. And like with anything its hard to why something is not grooving if your ears havent spent the reps listening and analysing what a good Groove sounds like. 

I know i might be over explaining. But incase someone else is reading and can get something from it. 🤓

author: Zack Hames
content:
I’m probably an outlier in the usual drum pack consumer but I’ll give you my take:

1. I found when there’s a million samples I get uninterested quickly. I’d prefer 2 snare sounds as opposed to 15 slight variations of nearly the same thing.

2. I use an MPC, so the lower volume thing would be annoying for my personal use, but that’s an outlier.

3. You could farm out the Battery / Kontakt / etc packs to friends who would be willing to do it or use those tools a lot, that way you’re not stuck making a ton of them (unless you want to of course) 

4. I don’t touch loops usually but I know tons of others do. 

5. That’s it. Sounds like a super fun and badass project! You should document it on the way on the discord

Edit: I’m speaking to more electronic and supplemental use of drum samples. There are probably tons of folks out there who want all the options as if there was 100% a real drummer recorded in their studio.

author: Deleted User
content:
1) Different tunings, Having clean vs processed, peaking at below -6, good velocity layers, round robin is good but not really necessary for me, I personally don’t need all mics separate but would like to have a separate room sample and the mixed sample as well.

2) Yes please!! I hate it when samples peak at 0. I actually turn all of them down when I put them into a sampler to make it peak at -8 to -12

3) small snippets of hihats or snare ghost notes and some tom loops. I’d probably prefer them mixed only

4) for kits I think it is important. Round robin and velocity layers, and if you are doing rooms or separate mics having a kit makes an instantly playable and tweakable kit.

5) I’m not sure. Anything between 44.1/16 and 48/24 should be fine! Anything beyond might be too much

author: LAPhill
content:
Read the EULA of the samples, but in most cases, it's totally fine to use samples and loops as long as you're not selling them on their own. As in, if you use a hi-hat loop in your track, you can't have a section that is JUST the hi-hat loop. That would also apply to delivering stems. Your "percussion" stem, for instance, should have other elements baked in with it.

That doesn't apply in all cases and there are certain samples out there that don't allow for sync use. I can't remember which ones offhand, but that's why it's worth checking the license agreement.

You’ve got your drums …..and built your vocal chops , the chops are like your keys part …..and then you’re gonna weave a stealthy , hooky baseline to syncopate and spin with your chops and drums . As an example ….you could do a dembow rhythm over your drums with your bass part and then jam your vocal chops into that feel …..or vice versa , a dem bow feel on the vocal chops and a stuttering walking bass line part with that .  

You ll quickly catch a groove between the drums vocal chops and bass hook 

Todd Edwards is the yoda of voxal chops

author: Rollmottle
content: As others have said, recreating a beat you like is the school you need to go to. One of my favorite beats of all time is Fleetwood Mac's "Hypnotized" which is a swingy, triplet unchanging thing that is effectively a drum loop through the song, except Mick Fleetwood plays it. I recreated it using a sample pack of Mick Fleetwood's and turned it into a song after serious finagling, especially in the context of grid music. The insight into accent, velocity, swing, where in the grid things hit (or don't), which specific hits matter and how dropping just one or two key hits in a repetitive pattern can shift the groove entirely. It also tests your chops for figuring out choke groups, how to make closed and open hi hats sound "real" (if that's your goal) so on and so forth. I also love recreating a beat as a way in when musical inspiration may be lacking.

author: Maxim
content:
Sounds like you’re looking for density without it being cluttered or overproduced. 

Usually “noise” (not literally but parts of the groove that you mainly feel but don’t make out specifically like you would a kick and snare or hi hat) serves this purpose for me. Elements which if muted would leave you feeling like something is missing but you can’t necessarily make them out when in. 

I guess this could be anything from a few percussion loops (maybe panned/verb with no pre-delay or less high end to place them at the back of the mix) to a subtle vocal or foley sample playing one note throughout the groove. 

Layering to me is part of this but my intent with it is usually to create a sound or get more out of an element (like layering the attack of a snap with a clap for a different transient / texture). But this doesn’t always add to “fullness” in my mind. It just makes one element better or more interesting. 

Maybe start with the loops and foley. Splice Bridge makes testing things really easy too.

author: ALXCPH
content:
Ahead of the Groove: listen JD Beck and domi, when they go off jd’s drums are Miles ahead. 

Behind the beat: anything by d’angelo with questlove(he is a wiz) 

Straight on beat: stay Justin and laroy. 

And thats just drums. 
Vocals, bass, percs and every other instrument is able to push and pull on a Groove to make it feel different. Like Matt Said, urgency , laid back, danceable, hectic, tight, fun, sad. 

Groove is a master of emotion combined with harmony.

author: ALXCPH
content: In a lot of trad Brazilian music, the groove moves and modulates during passages.(very human) but also very powerful. African grooves are usually late, Indian grooves ahead. This is VERy generalised by the way. It’s such a nuanced and complex topic. But it is very worth learning about!

author: delwin
content:
I do this a lot!

In Ableton, you have soooo many options. Most often I put the sample on an Ableton Simpler and am able to slice / pitch / etc really fluidly — record that, and then edit by hand. This is my workflow for 90% of vocal chops. If it’s really simple I’ll do it by hand but I find I get more musical results if I can “play” the chop. 

There’s also Buffer Shuffler and Beat Repeat in Ableton which can be fun and unpredictable. 

The Glitch Machines plugins are also really nice if you’re going for something a bit crazy (two of them are free and very good). I don’t fully understand them yet so I just throw them on when I want something wacky to happen. 

And I’ll also second stutter edit — very fun for “playing” chops live too, and editing presets isn’t too hard either.

author: ehutton21
content:
Vocalign is really essential to my work flow because of how many harmonies i get from clients & collaborators. I also create doubles with it a lot & use melodyne/alterboy to enhance the texture. 

As far as editing groove/timing, that’s hard cause I always cut that stuff until it feels right. Most of the time I’m gettin tracks where the artist or the producer or whoever (lots of times it’s the same person) has already agonized over the timing and cut it up so it’s solid. I’m mindful of words where the first syllable is cacophony or plosive-based (k, t, d) when it comes to sounds that hit on the quarter note (esp with snares). I usually let those sounds start just before the transient and end so that vowel is starting right on the note, depending on how it’s quantized if that makes sense. 

Feel like groove editing gets a weird wrap but i here songs where the timing could have used aligning after the amount of compression that got applied.

Does anyone have any rules-of-thumb that they rely on when programming groove?

Things like "I like my bass notes to be ___ in relation to the kick because..." or "I put my hats (blank) the snare because..." or "My (instrument) is 100% locked to the grid all of the time." 

Of course, everything is context dependent, so we're talking generalities here. But if you make nothing but trap music or lo-fi beats it would be good to mention that as well, for context.

I'm curious to know what approaches everyone else has arrived at. For better or worse, I like to start with a blank slate each time and it ends up being an exploratory process for me every time.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I asked a similar question a while ago, and @oaklandmatt had a great answer basically to the effect of: 
Something rushing ahead adds energy or anxiousness (a punk bass line or fast trap hihats, maybe a rock guitar solo)
Something late adds groove/swagger (Lofi hip hop snare, a lazy vocal, a funky bass line)
I think that’s a really cut and dry way to view it; but what you said obviously applies, every context is different.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
yeah its very case by case. as far as groove in relation to other elements. I've had guitars recorded loosely toa click and worked the groove around that - lining up the downbeats of the drums/bass  with the guitars even if it's a bit early or late. that was for a more indie type of joint. and for something more trap /modern hip hop, I've nudged bass notes or samples to get them to either sync w drums up for impact  or nudge slightly off to hype of of pull back the energy in the groove. 

as far as programming. I'll play with forward swing and dragging notes a lot if I'm going for a more real/dynamic feel when programming. keeping in mind that if the goal is trying to stay "on time" any fwd swing that might happen at the start of a phrase will be compensated with some drag  after or vice versa.  keeping velocities in mind w drum hits + linking it to a filter env so that harder hits have more high end and softer hits end up a bit rounder.

adding subtle layers that are similar   to the main drums but occupy a different texture or tone  in dif  sections to thicken up the groove or automate the attack /sustain of certain elements thru diff sections to help shift the listener  focus throughout

author: cy (sigh)
content: also if using an 808 switching up the length of the sustain in diff sections can shift the groove a lot without needing to change up top much in the actual drums. especially if you've got parallel compression going between kick and subs

author: Adam Thein
content:
I use both AD and SD.  

AD was easier for me to learn and jump into, but I'd say it's also a little more limited in how realistic you can get depending on the ADpaks you have.  Great for getting something in quickly, and I still use it quite a bit.

SD definitely had a learning curve for me but DAMN you can go deep if you really want to tweak out on drum programming.  There are tons of articulations, tons of microphones, and the expansions are all super in depth as well so you can shop around and figure out what is best.  It's definitely at a premium though for price, and I don't reach for it as often if I'm trying to get an idea out quickly, but I just used it today to play in some hihats because it sounds closer to real to my ears than AD.

The other thing I'd add about SD is the install size is pretty massive.  I have the core library with all the mics installed and their EZX kick and snares library and it's taking 250GB on one of my externals.  Oh by the way you can use any EZ Drummer libraries in SD which are more similar in depth to Addictive Drums stuff and they put out a few new libraries a year.

author: Slow Hand
content:
(Ok. Now I'm starting to run with this train of thought. Now would be a good time to step off if you've gotten what you need.)

I don't want this to sound like the end-all be-all. One of my absolute favorites is James Brown, and there is no way that some of his songs would hold up to the level of scrutiny I'm describing. And those records *kill*. It's all vibe. It's vibe all the way down, bebe. Not a chord change in sight. Barely a melody in some cases. And that's alright.

So what did James do? More often than not James would get all of his band (real jazz killers) in the studio and he would sing the parts to them one by one and allow them to input their own feel.

He'd start with the drummer and have them play a pattern that James was feeling. Once the drummer was jamming on that he would move on to the bass player and sing them an idea. Once the bass player had that germ of an idea they would continue to jam on it with the drummer, refining and adding their own thing. Then James would move on to the horns, and so on, and so on.

While James could be dictatorial and (from the perspective of music education) the least technically qualified person in the room he had *vision*. 

If the song has a strong identity you can give your players a good (non-technical) prompt and they can interpret that through their own sensibilities. You can describe a mood, or a scene, or an abstract sensation.

R. Kelly once said (I'm paraphrasing): "RnB is supposed to feel like the best moment of your *life*." That simple description conveys so much about the feel, the pleasure, and the joy that he is looking for in his music. It also excludes a lot of possibilities as well. If you can give your players a prompt like *that* then you can get everyone aligned on the same wavelength and it will carry you so much further without the need to dictate parts.

----

author: Ross Fortune
content:
From a cursory Synthtopia scan:

"So it seems that Luis Fernando Zepeda is part of the Organist generation of 60s-70s Mexico City with others like Evaristo Enriquez or Juan Torres.
This technique was “invented” by Tito Enriquez but perfected by Ernesto “Hill” Gil Olvera, whom was blind, and recorded LPs under the advertising that he played “the Organ that Talks!”

I found on a random blog that the drawbar configuration was something like this, you started with:
A = 88 8000 000 00
E = 80 8080 000 00
I = 80 0080 000 00
O = 80 8000 000 00
U = 80 0000 000 00

And you worked them with your left hand as you played with your right hand and play bass with with left foot and expression with right foot. It is a Hammond X66"


There's lots of Ernesto Gil Olvera stuff on YT, but I (and my nephew) don't like it is as much as this Luis Fernando Zepeda track. Can't find anything else by him unfortunately.

author: conor_i997
content: What are people’s main techniques for creating groove when programming drums. I know it depends but something I’ve heard is moving the hi hats slightly behind the grid and the snare slightly ahead. I also humanise the midi in logic to create more human like velocities and also mess with the swing. Just wondering if there’s any other ways of going about it

author: Deleted User
content:
Playing it or you can take a drum loop with groove you like and map out a groove template. Playing it is much faster and more feel, but often times it will need editing unless you have great timing. If it’s something loose then I’d definitely go ahead and move each notes because quantizing even 50% is going to change the feel. This is real nerdy but when there’s a really good moment in groove, I use logic’s event editor to look at how many ticks they are off by and snap other notes to somewhere near. For example, if I liked the feel of it being 40 ticks late then I’m gonna move everything (or some select notes that are in the same spot of the groove cycle) to somewhere nearby. Ticks are tempo relative so 50 ticks in 90bpm is different than 50 ticks in 120bpm. But it’s still in same relative timeline, but it’s going to feel different in different tempos. 

If you want it to groove like a drummer played it, best thing to do is play it in. You might end up quantizing or fixing velocity to al 127 later, but it’s going to be better than clicked in sequence if that is the style. Clicked in sequenced drums is its own groove too, you don’t want them having looseness so you quantize them all to 0 but you can still mess around with nudging them to be a bit behind or ahead of the grid.

author: Nick Hatzakos
Ross Fortune
content:
1) what are the top 5 most important things for you in purchasing a drum sample pack ?


I never purchase drum sample packs - not since having Splice. I do like a clear identity in a pack though - for instance, The Kount's sample pack has all those lo-fi/saturated kicks and snares, wonky grooves and crusty hi hats etc that sit very much in his genre, so if I'm reaching for that sound, I know exactly where to go. 

I don't know your drummer or his band, but I'd wonder what distinctive character you could capture in your pack? So that I know exactly where to go when I want "that" sound in a writing session instant. 


2) I’m always annoyed that all samples are 0.0db normalized and I always have to turned them way down to keep my gain staging coherent, would I be crazy to have them peak at -8 ? Would people automatically hate it ? 

I produce largely in Ableton now, and when you drop a sample in the drum rack, the instance of Simpler it creates defaults to -12dB. With the velocity:volume dial at default (45%), this causes a 0dB sample to play back at -6dB when velocity=100 (the default). My template has all mixer faders (including a basic drum rack + instance of Drum Buss) trimmed to -9dB (similar to my mix gain staging strategy I detailed previously), allowing me to mash stuff up if needed, and still have headroom to not have to max out vocals when it comes to cutting them. What I'm saying in a roundabout way is... I've already made allowances for 0dB samples, so I don't care - but you probably should, because if you're selling on Splice, they could sound dwarfed against the next pack.

author: Zack Hames
content:
My MPC Live is my right hand man in the studio as a writing tool. But when im NOT making records and mixing and recording, I make industrial music entirely on hardware. So the MPC is the daw in this case. No computer. 

If I’m using the MPC on a production where it isn’t the brain, it gets a little cumbersome, sometimes I make stuff on it and simply record it analog into pro tools. Other times I actually export the “stems” on the MPC as it’s very easy then take the sd card and drop the files into the session. This is a little time consuming but works and sounds great. 

There is MPC software/plugin that works with it! I just haven’t integrated it with my daw yet, but it seems legit. 

I don’t program drums on a piano roll ever, I always hit the pads.

author: Slow Hand
content:
@Josh I owned an NI Maschine+ (the standalone hardware unit) for a year before I eventually sold it. My reasons were much like yours; to get away from software and have a standalone instrument to play with.

I don't have many bad things to say about it, but ultimately it just wasn't a good fit for the way my brain works. NI have crammed a tremendous amount of features and functions into that thing. Most of which it does very well, but when it came time to do sequencing in the unit the interface was just too much of a hurdle for me. I found it hard to keep all of the key commands in my head to do simple commands. I think it's a little *too* efficient in how many options they've fit into it. Remembering the commands among it's unorthodox button layout was challenging and unintuitive for me.

As you might imagine, it integrates perfectly with the Maschine software, which is basically a DAW within a plugin that controls the hardware and vice-versa if you choose to use a computer. But I wasn't interested in that, because I can achieve the same things and more with plain old Ableton.

It *does* have a fantastic sample library and the NI sample packs you can purchase are very well done.

author: Slow Hand

author: Rob Domos
content:
As a dude who's musical education was mostly in accapella music and who's production has mostly been midi that was easily quantizable, my sense of rhythm is nowhere near tight enough for the tier of work that I've been entering into lately. This means if I play something, I'm going to need to be quantizing audio and I'm relying on the visual aid of the waveform because my inherent sense of groove is pretty weak. So I'm looking for advice on quick heuristics for quantizing audio. 

Todays example: I played some palm muted acoustic guitars, I've marked the scrape of the pick in red and the peak of the waveform where the note truly starts ringing in green. The waveform actually starts a little before the scrape as you can see where the pick touches the string wave over on the left . How are y'all thinking about which part of this waveform should fall on which side of the beat?

author: Rollmottle
content: In Ableton, I like fucking with the groove via the groove pool by mixing varying degrees of quantization and feel. Sometimes that can pocket something just right or pocket it in an interesting way.

author: Deleted User
content:
it’s generally the orange if it’s something like palm muted guitars. But always listen and feel it. It can feel better to be early in certain styles but it can feel better to be late on other styles. it also depends on who else is doing what

But groove template is always there if you wanna line it up with other instruments. bounce and make the source and destination audio files the same length, make sure the markers are in the correct place then sync them up. 

I’m 90% manual editing though. Because aligning automatically can fix notes I didn’t want to fix. you can also go measure by measure to be more careful if you want to auto align with groove templates 

you want to ask yourself “is this note late or early?” before making any moves. I like nudging with keyboard so I can fine tune how far it goes. 

Nowadays I’m more committed to “the only way to make the groove feel good is to play it that way”. I hate having to edit and to be honest, nothing beats well played rhythm section… Especially because I do a lot of in between the groove stuff, 30% quantization can mess with the feel of well landed notes. So I’m doing a lot of metronome practice these days

author: Rob Domos
content: To be embarrassingly transparent, a lot of times I think a note is late by listening and then after looking find out it was early. Things just feel in time or out. Also, a lot of things that have loose rhythm in a way that people tend to love often bother me and sound out of time to me. Jay-Z is a perfect example of this. I spent years thinking his rhythm was terrible before I realized he was doing a shuffle time feel where the amount his vocal is off from the snare creates the shuffle. I just didn’t pick up on that for like… 15 years? And just wondered why nobody else was bothered him being “out of time”. Kind of like when people with an undeveloped sense of harmony think of jazz as simply being an excuse for allowing wrong notes. That’s how I hear people that are famous for stretching rhythm

author: Deleted User
content:
makes me wonder if you were hearing other instrument that was on the grid - which was later the other instrument that is early, which led to a confusion of perceiving that the other instrument is late. 

also regarding the off-the-grid feel, listening isn’t to james brown or j-dilla isn’t going to do that for you. only playing along to it will get you used to the feel of pushing and pulling thing back and forward. 

but the fundamental is always on the grid stuff. I was in a huge J-Dilla phase for a while and I would try basically play things off for the feels. But it would sound like a mistake as opposed to intentional feel. and that was because I haven’t really mastered being right on the grid yet. I’m still working on being right on the grid by playing with metronome, and I found that actually improved my feel for all kinds of styles of groove. I still need to work on it, but it’s definitely better than before and I need less takes now. 

I know your question was about editing but I think there’s no better way to improve the sense of time and feel than to grab instruments and learn being what on time/late or early feels like.

author: Deleted User
content:
But I do want to clarify about my one take musician thing… 

I may have used the term too loosely. To me, most jazz musicians are one take players. They record everything together and calls it. (of course they do a few takes but I’m not trying to be a “first take and that’s it” player)

Being able to play through the whole song (unless arrangement calls for section by section) and just needing to punch in a few spots is what I want. I do not have any desires to go beyond that. 

BUT

I don’t ever want to edit my timing other than micro adjustments that can be done by moving small part of audio clip or hitting quantize. 

That + being more consistent with touch so I don’t have to punch in as much

author: Deleted User
content:
re: 1 

I have gotten over the whole “perfectionism” thing. I still overthink all the time but I can confidently day I am free of perfectionism. I have no problem letting go when it calls for it. I believe there’s a difference between wanting to be better and working towards it vs not being able to move on out of fear and holding onto something without knowing the next move. If that was the case I wouldn’t have sent what I first recorded to the artist. I may have wasted some time thinking I would be able to get this part down, but I don’t think I was being a perfectionist by doing that. 

re: 2

Why would he do this if he’s a great guitarist? Is it a workflow preference or the aesthetic of edit/sampling? I can only imagine it being faster playing the parts in rather than stitching bits together. 



The whole goal is to be able to consistently reproduce that magical groove, and being able to create great moments when I am with other people. I really believe I have a good sense of groove but can’t execute it just yet. 

I can see myself spending countless hours editing myself. (Which I already do daily). That time is better spent working on my chops. If I can hire other musicians so I can stop wasting time trying multiple takes, I would. But I don’t have that just yet. I go by sections or measures most of the time, I don’t just sit there trying to nail ONE perfect take.

author: spectrummasters
content:
3. Groove / feel 

Focus the groove  on a shuffle around beat 3 in every bar .

author: spectrummasters
content: Once you’ve got that shuffle around the 3 with hi hats and extra snare samples you’re moving .

author: spectrummasters
content: More hat and snare samples can then be used as quieter layers to start layering shuffles in other parts between the beats . The first 16th after the downbeat and a 16th before the the offbeat in beat 2 and 4 all work , but it’s then much more about velocity really . The idea is your hats and snares all start shuffling into each other , through the bar , again with the accent around the 3 . Resolving in beat 4 and back around for the next downbeat

author: spectrummasters
content:
Because it’s an open and minimal drum production listen to Calvin harris and the disciples how deep is your love 

In this house style you want to really experiment with note velocities and swing settings (how far you push the swing ) to get it spinning. U.K. producers wrote early house and garage with the grid on 1/24 (triplets ) for the snares and hats . So we are talking take your swing potentially all the way to triplet time  . 

Kick is to have subtle little syncopations and doubles to push the groove (before transitions/ on turnarounds  for example )

author: spectrummasters
content: Listen to the accent around beat 3 in every bar

author: spectrummasters
content: This record is by grant Nelson who is one of the originals who took US New York garage and removed the kick on beats 2 and 4 to create the first U.K. 2 step garage tracks . On this record he returned to mainstream house and you should hear immediately the dem bow pulse on the baseline hook

author: Deleted User
content:
Art is subjective, so there’s actually no “better” — This is something I need to remind myself of more. The amount of times that I showed something that I thought was good and was rejected, and the times I showed something I hated and got good reactions from  people. You really never know! 

I’ve been doing more writing sessions these days (once or twice a week or so), and I’m really falling in love with this because I can get out of my own head and look around to get a sense of whether an idea is working or not outside of my own opinions

Speaking of the relentless will to finish: would it be a producer’s job to stay on top of getting others in team to get their parts done? If I’ve done my part already and completed it, do I keep bothering them to get their parts done? (lyrics etc) 

I read your reply to someone asking about writing sessions, and you said your biggest goal is to get the vocals from the first spark of inspiration on that same day. I’ve had sessions where I get a basic bone of ideas with beat done, and top line is done but the lyrics are recorded in Gibberish and stream of consciousness. I would return, complete the arrangement on my own - send it back, they said they fuck with it and tells me they will finish the lyrics. How long do I wait, do I follow up at all, or do I just move on and keep making more? I don’t want to overstep or rush people (and.. I can’t get anyone to anything of course), but I also want to get the song done while I’m excited so I can keep moving forward. It’s hard to tell if I can even do about it or if I should just keep it moving and leave it be

author: Adam Thein
content:
The only way I trust time editing multitrack sources like drums in Ableton is linking the channels (right click menu option when you have multiple tracks selected) and like Josh said slicing manually in front of each transient and sliding the audio to where you’d like it to be.

Other daws are much better suited to automating this workflow like Beat Detective in Pro Tools or a similar style workflow in Logic I forget the name of.  Studio one has a similar workflow that I also forget the name of.

author: Adam Thein
content: Beat Detective is pretty easy to pick up with a tutorial even if you don't use much else in Pro Tools.  I will say I think Logic's drum editing features are a little closer in style to the way warp markers work in Ableton, but you can also use it similarly to beat detective which makes it another good option, especially on a budget.

author: chris_donlin
content: Need some advice here! I've been working with an artist for a little over a year, have made 8 or 9 songs. We've had to retrack vocals for nearly every song because the performance just isn't quite there yet, but we always get it where we want it in the second session. I'm noticing a pattern of him sitting with the vocal and realizing he wants to sing it differently/better, but only feels this after we've tracked it once. Today was day 1 tracking vocals on a new song and it got to the point where i realized we were going to have to try again another day, I was felt fed up. I tried to discern what exactly i was frustrated at. Part of me was frustrated because it doesnt seem like he is ever truly prepared to track vocals, in the sense of being warmed up, having ideas of how he wants to sing, practicing ahead of time, singing random stuff in between takes, etc. The other part of me was frustrated with myself because im aware some of the responsibility falls on me as the producer/coach. I have no problem taking time to edit the vocal, i know it's part of the job, i enjoy it in fact haha - but is it fair to have certain expectations from him as the artist? I want to have a conversation with him about it but also be clear that i want to be better at my job too

author: Zack Hames
content:
So, I think it’s superbly underrated. Especially the new Akai MPC lives, one, etc series.

I use it as a drum machine/sampler/sequencer for all of my hardware synths. It’s the brain and controller for everything.

But you can also use it completely on its own, you can put any sample all the way across a keyboard/pads to the correct pitch automatically. 

There are built in AIR effects. You can time stretch, etc do whatever with samples. 

Load up any drum samples and go to town. 

It also has some built in instruments / synths, but I rarely use those. 

It’s essentially a portable DAW as far as music production. I prefer it to computer by far for producing / writing with samples and synths

author: JakeTB
content:
Ableton has lots of workflows- how are doing your programming?

The playback should be the same as any other daw, but there are a couple traps that come up. 

-If you’re doing drag-and-drop, check that automatic fades at clip edges is turned off in your preferences
-If you’re using Drum Rack/Simpler, try turning off the filter  in the bottom left

author: vostral
content:
Here are two samples including a static loop and a groovy loop.
- On the static loop, I use DX drum machine HiHat and just barely put them 1/8 on the grid

- On the programmed loop, I adjust the gain up & down for each hat piece, fade in/out to get varied length, time adjusting, and finally a Tremolo.

=> These make such a big improvement in the feel. This is crucial for anyone using samples instead of real drum machines or Kontakt…

author: vostral
content: P/s: I use Oberheim DX Hihat from Samples From Mars. They have a huge collection of drum machines samples!

author: Isaac Diskin
content: Does anyone have any knowledge regarding creating PGM/SND files for an MPC 2000? Producer I work with asked me to figure this out but info online is quite contradictory so if anyone has any experience with this I would love to chat.

author: Isaac Diskin
content: Oh cool! I want to bring wav files from computer onto the MPC, and I know they need to first be converted to SND / PGM files. Studio computer is a Mac running Ventura and the MPC has a SD drive as well.

author: aliberger
content: the mpc2000 reads wav files! if they're not working i'd check that they're 16 bit/44.1khz

author: aliberger
content: snd is the mpc's native format for saving sounds, once you get the wavs loaded into memory i believe they can be saved as snd files. pgm files are programs (data like which sample is assigned to which pad and all the parameters around that) which you create on the mpc. programs don't contain any sound data themselves, they reference the sounds by filename

author: spectrummasters
content: You are going to run into a problem between the mpc and the computer when transferring files . The mpc runs FAT 12

author: spectrummasters
content: Build a new naming protocol for the MPC

author: spectrummasters
content: Remember all files transferred to the MPC can only be 16 bit

author: spectrummasters
content:
You can choose save all
Programs and sounds once you’ve transferred them in and you can set to save the waves as .snd format . I would not recommend using .snd  at all . There’s no gain to be made . You’re building a sound library in a format that’s incompatible with your computers finder 
The Mpc and your computer share compatibility for wav . That’s the format that will allow you to always preview your mpc built sound libraries in the future on a computer

author: spectrummasters
content: So , you can do computer wavs ->mpc .snd via digital transfer (floppy / flash card or spdif) but you’re circumventing perhaps the best part of the mpc (the sampler ) and gonna run into file naming and format problems

author: spectrummasters
content: But , it is a YES. To what your producer wants to do and if you get stuck just ask I’ll talk you through it . Do you have a copy of the MPC 2000 xl manual ? It’s v v good and will explain all this

To me those drums kinda do sound like towel over the snare in a mostly dead room, with some processing (mainly shortened decay/release).

You could get that kind of sound with many libraries, but the ones that come to mind are

https://www.circlesdrumsamples.com/dead
https://www.xlnaudio.com/products/addictive_drums_2/adpak/vintage_dead

The addictive drums pack is a bit of a weird one, it contains a lot of samples from their previous libraries, just with shortened decays/releases
